Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Technology and Design Entrepreneurship and Innovation Ecosystem at Rochester Institute of Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps Site at Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) will increase the quality and quantity of commercializable student projects, leveraging its core strengths in diversity and experiential learning to advance innovation, entrepreneurship, and commercialization outcomes.

RIT has a track record for innovation. The Simone Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship's Student Incubator advanced approximately 100 multidisciplinary teams during 2012. These teams are supported by the Simone Center's faculty Innovation Council with representatives from all of RIT's colleges. Funding from the NSF I-Corp program will expand the number of teams that will receive funding for prototyping/proof of concepts supplies, coach expense, and exploratory customer market activities. The Simones Center's approach to entrepreneurship is experiential and multidisciplinary. RIT is situated to pioneer an I-Corps Site because of its history with experiential learning (coop, industry relationships, history of practitioners in the classroom etc.) and its program diversity. The Simone Center programs integrate technology, design, and business perspectives in a holistic manner. Teams simultaneously enter a program with formalized training and curriculum and weekly coaching by an experienced cohort of industry-based entrepreneurs and product developers.

This proposal provides broader impacts to society and Rochester region in several ways:
-The Creation of Entrepreneurial Assets: RIT will increase the number of graduates with an emphasis on STEM and design with business creation/tech commercialization knowledge, experience, and teams building skills to innovate throughout their careers.
-New Ventures: The Student Incubator has and will continue to create a variety of companies that have growth and provided economic development to the struggling Rochester Region.
-Pipeline Development: RIT will provide a pre-seed/early stage pipeline for potential new ventures.
-Successful Undergraduate Innovation Processes: This program promotes and advances the development of balanced student teams, experienced coaching, and access to university support services (prototyping labs, faculties, and other expertise).
-Integration with a Preexisting Business Incubator: The Simone Center's programs and events target early stage business development. The Simone Center's Student Incubator Program transitions its investment ready projects/businesses to the pre-existing RIT Incubator allows each unit to focus on the a specific stage of new venture creation. This is also a potential process for learning and dissemination.
This is a project at an institution that serves a very large population of deaf students (the largest population in the nation). It has processes in place that will accommodate those and the other RIT students to explore entrepreneurship and innovation - 90% of all RIT students engage in a co-op experience. The Site design is student-centric, having the joint impact of launching innovative products and immersing students in an entrepreneurship curriculum. RIT has a track record of successes - in particular, they have a history of launching "game-centric" and visual media products.


The Site has the potential to have a large regional impact in a part of the country that has been economically depressed. There is a large team of volunteers willing to mentor students as well as an Advisory Board to guide the programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RIT was selected as an NSF Site in 2015 and renewed in 2018.  In our recently submitted grant summary report we described how RIT has evolved and matured its I-Corps Site program over the past 5 years to improve integration of I-Corps best practices and RIT’s unique institutional environment. The past year witnessed very significant adjustments in all RIT I-Corps courses due to the COVID-19 environment. Most our programs moved from face-to-face (traditional) instruction to virtual or blended delivery beginning in March 2020. 

This brief report describes our programs’ response to COVID-19, advancements in our deaf inclusion initiatives and provides outcome data.

COVID-19 Responses

RIT’s I-Corps program portfolio shifted delivery mechanisms since the outbreak of COVID-19 to better reflect student and faculty needs.  COVID-19 affected RIT’s I-Corps Site in a variety of ways.  During the pandemic, many RIT students lost or were unable to find co-op opportunities. As the number of technology co-ops dramatically declined, RIT sought to significantly expand the full-time I-Corps Student Accelerator to provide new opportunities to entrepreneurial students.  Because many of these students did not have well shaped technology concepts, the Simone Center worked with technology businesses and RIT researchers to identify additional concepts. As a result, the Simone Center modified elements of its existing Student Accelerator to form a new program, named Innovation Fellows. Like the Student Accelerator, it is a 14 week, full-time program, where students learn I-Corps methodologies, conduct customer discovery and business model development, and create an early stage, minimum viable product. The program differs from the traditional Accelerator Program in that many of the ideas originate with researchers and technology companies, as opposed to the students themselves.

National Deaf I-Corps Initiative

Another important area of development this past year has been RIT’s advancement in outreach and training to the (university-based) national deaf community. RIT’s National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID) is a leader in Deaf STEM education. Over the past several years, RIT has developed unique I-Corps content to address Deaf needs, particularly related to developing communications strategies for interacting with the hearing community. With the support of an NSF Inclusion grant and a partnership with Gallaudet University, RIT created a national synchronous online I-Corps short course for Deaf students. The program is unique for the following reasons: it’s co-taught by Deaf faculty members; provides access to Deaf mentors; and addresses the unique needs of the Deaf community.  In the past year this program has significantly increased its presence and awareness among the deaf community.

This past year, RIT was awarded a supplemental NSF grant to create a native language (in this case American Sign) asynchronous online course. This course, scheduled for completion later this year, will link Deaf participants from around the nation with the RIT Deaf mentor network. Additionally, RIT is also in the process of creating a unique clearing house web site tailored to the needs of the Deaf and hard of hearing, which will support individuals seeking to advance early stage technology concepts. 

Outcomes: Training (Previous year: Fall 2019, Spring 2020, Summer 2020, early Fall 2020)

I-Corp training programs described including enrollment/participation: 

  • I-Corps Short Courses (General, Topics Specific:  Access and Inclusion Technology)
    • [1 section: 8 teams/19 participants] 
  • National Online I-Corps Course for the Deaf
    • [1 section: 4 teams/10 participants]
  • I-Corps 3 Hour Credit Course.
    • [Multiple sections: 68 teams/120 participants]
  • I-Corps Full-time Student Accelerator/Innovation Fellows Program.  Co-op enabled program for students with technology oriented business concepts.    
    • [4 sections: 42 teams/133 participants] 
  • I-Corps Modules in Existing Courses and Programs.  As with many universities I-Corps methodologies have now been included in many entrepreneurial, product development, marketing, and design courses and programs.   
    • [Multiple courses with I-Corps Modules]   

 

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2020
Modified by: Richard Demartino
